South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: EYPTIAN TRUST and INVESTMENT Ltd. (in liquidation)
div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that those shareholders in the above Company who have not yet paid all their calls on shares held by them must pay same on or before the 30th October 1906 to the Company's Bankers, the Anglo-Egyptian Bank Limited, Alexandria.

Having regards to the amalagamtion of the Egyptian Trust and Investment Ltd. with the Bulding Lands of Egypt it is necessary that all calls should be paid by the date above indicated, and futher, shareholders owing calls will be unable to obtain their new shares in exchange for their present ones until they have paid their shares up in fall. In the meantime, until payment of the calls, interst is accruing against sharesholders until payment in made, at the rate of 10% per annum.
Alexandra, 9 October, 1906.
By order,
GEO. T. BROADBRIDGE,
Liquidator.

div.head: EYPTIAN TRUST and INVESTMENT Ltd. (en liquidation)
div.p: AVIS

Messiurs les actionnaires de l'Egyptian Trust and Investment Ltd. (en liquidation) sont prevenur que les versements des deuxieme et troisieme appels de 5/. sur les actions de l'Egyptian Trust and Investment Ltd., qui auraient du etre verses le 21 Juillet et le 21 Aout selon les avis publies, devront etre affectues sux guichets de l'Anglo Egyptian Bank Ltd. a Alexandria avant le 30 Octobre 1906.

En vue de la fusion de l'Egyptian Truast and Investment Ltd. avec la Building Lands of sements soiet effectues entierement avant la date mentionnee cihaut faute de quoi Messieurs les actionnaires ne pourrount plus echanger leur titres.

div.head: Commerical and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette."
div.p: The Commerical and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceeding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the offical telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, ete., etc. Sunscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra.). For Further particulars apply to the Manager "Egyptian Gazette."

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: The weater continues agreeable; but every now and then the sky clouds over and rain appears to be threatening. The wind is now easterly and barometer steady.

div.head: FRANCE AND THE SAHARA.
div.p: There have recently appeared in the French Press interesting accoutns of the attempted occupttion and exploration of the western Sahara desert by French foreces, coming on the one hand from Algeria and on the other from the Niger. A year of two ago, before the respective spheres of influenced, the different French possessions had been defined, a certain amount of friction resulted from the rival adventures of native soldiers in French service entering the Sahara from the Niger, and those coming from Algeria. Now, however, that the respective spehres of influence of Algeria and West Africa have been regulated, the camel corps of both regions can faternize cordially when they meet in the heart of the Great Desert, that desert which is so rapidly being opened up now to our konwledge.

The French, have says the "Tribune," effected much of their peaceful occupation of the Sahara by means of well equipped camel corps. In the summer of this year, an expedition of camel cavarly, under Colonel Laperinine, reached the salt mines of Taodeni, to the south of the desert of Igidi, where they found negroes at work quarrying the salt, which is spread all over the regions of Nigeria as marketable product. The journey from the oasis of Twat, however, was of an unusually arduous character. The little banf of camel riders had to travel over several stretches of more than a hundred miles each "without any pastu age for their beasts, and with no water in the wells fit to drink. At a well called Tuihaya, to the north of Taodeni, the drinking water looked and tasted exrremely soapy, and was simply diluted posion. Everyone who drank of it swelled out to a monstrous

extent, and although all the sufferes recovered they had to halt at this place serveral days until their bodies resumed normal proportions. Three bottles of this terrible water have been sent to be analysed at Algeries.

It is considered that the best route fot he TRans-Saharan Railway would lie to the east of Taodeni. It would, of course, be directed from Timbuktu to the oasis of Twat. Twait is at no very great distance form the terminatoin of the existing railway near the oasis of Figii several hundred miles to the south of Oran. The distance to be covered between Twat and Timbuktu is about 700 miles, or about 150 miles longer than the existing Uganad Railway. There are, in short, about a thousand miles of railway required to connect the railways system of NOrth Africa with Timbuktu and the navigable Niger. If only French economies were wisely directed instead of finding every now and then their grave in a "Panama," this railway might easily and quickly be made, and the advantage to the commerce and power of France in the northern half of Africa would be enormous.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COMMERCE.
div.p: The Cairo correspondent of "Africa Engineering" writes:- The autumn has come, and most of us here are standing by for the return of the big guns from Europe. Meanwhile, a bumper season is confidently looked forward to. All crop returns are favourable, and there is a continual rise in values of building and gricultural land thorughout Egypt and the Sudan.

In building-construction material shippers of cheap Belgian girders will find a ready market, although there is some faint hope that the British Administration of Egyptian affairs will at length admit British standard measurements and the Engineering Standard Committee's list of rolled sections to an equality with Continental ones in spefications for Government work. Conrete block builidng is likely to come into favour, and I understand that the new Sermiramis Hotel, facing the Nile, has been carried out on this entirely new principle among local contractors.

Since the products of the Societe Anonyme des Ciments d'Egypte - a Belgian conern - have been officially admitted for the Punic Works specifications, shippers of British Portland cement will find competition keener than ever. Domestic sanitary appliances will also, of course, be required, and Briitsh makers might with profit pay some attention to the manufacture of Arab servants' conveniences in earthenware and cast iron. These are patterned on the old French model, which suits the native habits.

In matters agricultural there will be increased demand for European machinery, and makers of large centrifugal pump with a guranteed efficiency, and steam ploughing and levelling plant ought to book some good orders from certain of the land companies who are now at work reclaiming and improving the soil by scientific methods.

British manufacturing engineering firms should not be deterred form paying attention to the requirements of the market by more or less interested Press statements about the financial risks incurrred. Owing to the total absence of anything approaching an organized engineering industry, Egypt is largly a dealers' marke, and it suits a great many of them get the native buyer into their debt. By reason of their large profits dealrs can well afford to grant the long credits so foten referred to as obligatory, but manufacturers will find - as indeed, a great many have found - that a square deal can always command a cash value.

I would like to say, in reply, that the legal machinery is ample to protect any shipper who exercise ordinary business precaution, and is far more prompt to act than at home, while as regard German firms it is to be notes that of all nationalists they are least likely to give credit where none is due. To give an isntance of their touching confidence in this respect, I would remark that a well-konwn German firm, having recently obtained a large order from a Government Department, insisted upon part of the purchase money, amounting to some thousands of pounds, being paid over to thembefore even putting the prelimininary drawings in hand. In face of facts of this kind it is idle to dogmatise on the way British firms should or should not conduct their business in Egypt, apparently without any regard to the status of the selling firm, the nature of the merchandise, or the standing of the customer.

div.head: Legislative Council.
div.p: The Legislative Council will hold their next meeting in Cairo on Monday.

div.head: Asile Rudolph.
div.p: The Rev. Peter Rudolph has received a nation of £1 for the Asile Rudolph from Mr. Anderson Neary, of Shillelagh Castle.

div.head: Department of Public Health.
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior, acting upon the advice of the Department of Public Heath, has authorized M. Anosto'os J. Convelas, chemist to pratice in Egypt.

div.head: Egyptian Ivory.
div.p: Twenty one tons of Egyptian ivory had arrived last week date at London for the Quarterly Sales, and the toal beig forty tons, this county has so far provided more than 50 per cent.

div.head: The National Univeristy.
div.p: Hussein Bey El Bakri writes from Damietta to "Al Moayad" and "Al Mokattam" contradicting the report that he had sunscribed L.E. 1,000 for the estbalishment of the National University.

div.head: Beiram Holidays.
div.p: The Government schools will be closed from the 15th to 23rd inst. for the Courban Beiram Holidays. During Ramdan they will be open from 9 a.m. to 3.30 p.m. and the kuttabs from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail.
div.p: The mail for despatch via the Port Said Brindisi route will be made up at 3.10 p.m. on Sunday for ordinary correspondence and one hour earlier for registered letters. Insured articles and money orders will be received for despatch up to noon and parcels up to six o'clock tomorrow evening.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail.
div.p: The mail for despatch via the Port Said Brindisi route will be made up at 3.10 p.m. on Sunday for ordinary correspondence and one hour earlier for registered letters. Insured articles and money orders will be received for despatch up to noon and parcels up to six o'clock tomorrow evening.

div.head: Cairo Argicultural Show.
div.p: We believe it is the intention of the Khedivial Agricultural Society to make their next show in Cairo more of an industrial exhibition. An effort will be made to have the whole of the industries of the country represented and this should prove a great attraction to the many visitors to Cairo in the season.

div.head: Army of Occupation.
div.p: A large number of homegoing details of the Cairo garrison arrived at Alexandria this morning and embarked on the transport Sicilia for passage home. There were also some details from the Alexandria garrison, who marched down to the quay headed by the banf of the Royal Dublin Fosiliers. The Sicilia sails this sails this afternoon for Malta.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: On 10th October 7 vessels, of which 4 were northward and 3 southward bound, transited the canal, and paid for transit and passenge toll Fr. 198,460.97 Of these 4 were British, 2 German, and 1 Russian. The total receipta since October 1 are Fr. 2,580,213.11, and during that time 99 vessels transited the Canal, 45 being nothward, and 54 southward bound.

div.head: A Little Cirl's Callantry.
div.p: Our Sohag Correspondent writes: Two little grils of the ages of six and ten years were playing by the bank of a canal when the younger child fell into the water. Her sister made a brave attempt to save her, but both children were downed, and their bodies have not yet been recovered. Great indignation is expressed at the refusal of the police to search for the bodies until tomorrow.

div.head: Balloons for the Nile.
div.p: Major B. F. S Baden Powell advocates a trial being made in East Africa, southward up the valley of the Nile Uganda and the Equater; and to put a conclussion to the exploration of Egypt, he suggests the use of seven asscociation being empted as encessary in to those remaining and the evelopes discharges instead of ballast. Major Baden Powell in an authority, and has been secretary of the Aeronautical Society, but that kind of exploration would probably be more expensive than its results would justify. Funds, indeed, have been forthcoming for very few enterprising ballooning schemes.

div.head: A Little Cirl's Burnt to Death.
div.p: A horrible accident, which took place the day before yesterday, is reported from what is known as the Arab town of Port Said. A little girl, seven years of age, of a Greek bakery was seated enar a lighted spirit lamp when it exploded and set fire to her clothes. Her momther and two sisters ran to the rescue, but were themselves surrounded by flames and it was only with great difficulty that the neighbours succeeded in extinguishing them. The four vicitims were immediately removed to hospital, where the little girl died shortly afterwards.

div.head: The Suez Route.
div.p: The P. and O. steamship Delhi arrived at Hong Kong on the afternoon on the evening of August 24 letters having thus been 244 days in transit. The despatch of this mail from London eastwards was simultaneous with that of the mail sent west wards by the Canadian route, the latter arriving at Hong Kong on Sept. 23, and delivering the mails in 29 ½ days. On this showing, therefore, the Suez route is five days shorter than that via Canda. The departure of the Delhi from Hong Kong to Shanchai was retarded owing to the typhoon which interfered with coaling arrangments. Otherwise, it is thought, the mail via Suez would have reached Shanghai at the same time as that via Canada, it not somewhat earlier.

div.head: New Employment Registry.
div.p: The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has cummenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring cleriesal or other assitance. Applications will be received free of charge from clearks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria.

div.head:
TANTAH AGRICULTURAL SHOW.
KHEDIVE GREATLY INTERESTED.
div.p: (FROM OUR SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT).

In my wire to you this morning, I was able to give an account of the proceedings in connection with the Khedivial Agricultural Society's Show up to the reception held by the Khedive on the show ground. This reception was held under a beautiful marquee, which contained a number of gilt-backed chairs for the accomodation of those honoured by his Highness, who included the members of the comittees of the society, the provinical, notables, the ulema, clergy, consular corps, etc.

At the conclusion of the recption a move was made to the banquetting tents, in one of which the Khedive preaided over a luncheon of 110 covers. In other tents no less than 400 guests of the lolcal Municipality sat down to an excellent luncheon, the arrangements for which, as for the other, were in the hands of the Nungovich Hotels Company, which is as good as sayig that they were perfect.

After luncheon, the Khedive went over the spacious show ground, which covers an area of fourteen feddans, and inspected to the whole of the exhibits, evincing the liveliest interest in everything. His Highness's knowledge of matters argricultural is so well known that this was only to be expected. At the end of his tour, on which he was accompanied by H.H. Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel (president of the society) and the Ministers, the Khedive was graciously pleased to express himseld as being higly satisfied with everything he saw, and congratulated the secretary Mr. G. P. Fosden (who conducted his Highness over the show ground) on the great success of his efforts. In these efforts we may state that Mr. Foaden was very ably seconded by Mr. Goodchild, who was in charge of the society's local arrangment, and was likewide congratulated by his Highness, also Mohamed Effendi Hussein, the local secretary.

Returning to the receotion tent, the Khedive once more held a reception, this time the cultivators of Lower Egypt, accopanied by the moudirs of their respective moudiriebs being received by his Highness. In the tent with his Highness. In the tent with his Highness was remarked Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel, Fakbry Pasha and his son, Sir Vincent Corbett, Mr. Machell, Mr. Mitchell Innes, etc.

The reception over, a parade of the winning animals in the show was held in a ring before his Highness. One thing that struck me in this parade was the marked superiority of the mares over the stallions exhibited.

The end of the parade marked the conlucsion fo the Kehdive's visit, and after bidding good-bye to the officals, his Highness drove away, as he had come, accompanied by his Body Guard, to the station, where his special train was in readiness at 3.15 p.m. to convey him back to Alexnadria.

It only remains to be said that the whole of the arrangements connecte with the Khedive's visit were excellent, not a single hitch having occurred. The police organization was especially good, and for this Moberly Bey was mainly responsible. The huge crowds which lined the streets were kept in perfect order. It is calculated that something like 7,000 or 8,000 strangers visited Tantsh for the opening of the show and the strain thrown on the staff of the railway may easily be imagined. With the exception of a somewhat uncontrollable crush at the booking offices, however, everthing passed off wonderfully well.

The general public was admitted to the show after the Khedive's departure, and the ground was crowded throughout the afternoon. It may be interesting to note that the exhibit of horses numbered 150, while there were 170 mares, 200 mules, 90 donkeys, and 60 camels. The exhibits of cotton, some of which were remarkably fine, totalled close on 1,700 and those of grain 1,000.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: On his arrival from Tantah at five o'clock yesterday afternoon the Khedive went to Montazah palace. His highness attened prayers this morning at Montazah mosque.

div.head:
ANARCHY OF THE PRESS.
FRAUDULENT REPORTS.
div.p: "Al Mackattam" remarks that the anarchy of our Press has led some of our conferes to committ several grave and even indictable breaches of proprity. We refer to fraudulent reporting and the falisifcation of signatures.

We now learn that a number of the statements attributed to Me. Ibrahim Bey Helbawi were never uttered by the well known advocate and that several names have appeared in the subscription list wihout the authorisation of their bearers.

A propose of this we may mention a little adventure that recently befell Kassem Bey Asmin. One of our conferees lately dared to publish a letter purporting to come from the well known author and legist, and containg a palindos - an absolute recantaiton of his proposals for the emanicpation of the Moslem women. Kassem Bey had of course written no arch letter and was note ven aware of the existence of the journal et fault till a cutting was shown him.

div.head:
THE SULTAN'S BIRTHDAY.
CELEBRATIONS AT BEYROUT.
div.p: Our Beyront correspondent writes under date of the 8th inst.:-

For the Faithful the aniversary of the Sultan's birthday should be an occasion of greater joyfulness than that of his Majesty's Acession; for the former marks the memeroable date on which, not only a sovereign, but, also, a Caliph and a spirtual chief came for them to the world. And yet this time there seemed to be a certain lack of enthusiasm in the festive demonstrations of the Moslem public. The rumors about his Majesty's illness, so wildly published by every section of the European Press, may be reponsible for this absence of a free jubilant note in the festive display, incidental to such an important event of state in Turkey.

The official expression of the fete, however, was made in the usual way. Indeed, the manner of the Vali seemed to be marked with such as particularly natural cheerfulness that it inclined one to seriously doubt the recent wild rumours respecting his Majesty's recarious condition of health. Inded, the easy grace and natural courtesy of manner with which he holds public receptions is a gift of his Excellency.

Early on Thursday morning a regiment of soldiers was drawn upabout the Seraglio, where Khali Pasha, the Governor Gneral, received in state the Ulema and clerical dignitaries, as well as the civil and military officials, the Consular Corps, and notabiliites of the town. At about 10.30 a.m. his Excellency proceeded in state to the barracks to return the visits of the commandant of the Garrison and the Military Staff, The Commandant, Hakki Pasha, was indisposed and Reasar-Admiral Faiek Pasha received in his stead. In the reception hall of the barracks one observes on entering the portrait of his Majesty with an immense painting underneath, represting the Turkish armorial ensigns, while on the opposite wall stands the famous life-size portrait of the German Emperor in the imperial robe of state, symbolizing the unwritten alliance between the two Empires:

After the usual exchange of courtesis the Vali proceeded to the military hospital, and visited the sick saying to each a kind and cheering word. This seems to me the fittests and most touching act to be performed by a Governor on his Sovereign's birthday.

In the evening the Seraglio and the building of the Dragools near by, as well as the harracks, and other public buildings, such as the telegraph and post offices, the Gas Company's office, the Imperial Ottoman Back and certain private buildings as well, emerged in wreaths of light. The full moon, however, robbed the gass ullumination of their effect. The new place of the Imperial Ottoman Bank, on the quay near the Custom House, was the most tastefully illuminated, the girdle of light, with the beautiful crescent and star at each end, and the motto in Turkish of "Long LIve the Sultan" in the middle, set off in conspicuous letters of light, relieving the otherise heavy architectural effect of this picturesque uet erase edifice.
The vali held a reception till 11 p.m. in the big kiosk of the City Garden, El Minshiye, where refreshments were served, and the military band played all the while.

div.head: THE RAYAK-HAMA RAILWAY.
div.p: HAMA ALEPPO SECTION.
(FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT.)

The inauguration of the Hama-Aleppo section constituting an extension of the Rayak-Hama railway took place on the 4th instant, the anniversary of the Sultan's birthday. No particulars are yet to hand of the banquet given on this occasion, and to which it is said forty persons were to be invited. There was to be an immense pavilion improvised for the occasion.

The length of this section is about 143 kilometres while the total length of the line from Rayak to Aleppo is 331 kilometres. The line is of the standard type, having a width of 1,435 metres and is endowed with a kilometric guarantee of 15,000 francs. As this line is at present dependent on the narrow cogwheel line of Beyront Famascus it is feared that its chance of development and success will not be great, unless the narrow line should be super seded by another broad gauge line that will o away with the runions transhipment system at Rayak necessitated by the unequal width of the two lines.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Creole Prince left London on the 10th inst. with passengers and general cargo, and is due to arrive at Alexnadria on er about, the 26th October.
The Khedivial express mail steamship Isamilia will leave Alexandria at 4 p.m. on Wednesday for Piraens, Smyrna, Mitylene, and Constantinople.
The Mosliner Menes sailed from Liverpool last Wednesday, and is due here about the 24th inst. with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
The Moss liner Menepthath arrived yesterday evening from Liverpool, via Gibraltar, Algiers and Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
The Florio Rubattino S. S. Memfi is due here on Sunday, 14th inst. from Messins.
The S.S Flavio Giois, of the same lines, with passengers and cargo is due here from Naples on Thursday, 18th inst.

div.head:
THE FIRST SIRDAR.
EGYPTIAN REMINISCENCES.
div.p: Sir Eveya Wood has just published his memoirs, which contains some interesting sideligths in Egyptian history.

The Field Marshal will ever be remembered as the creator of the native Egyptian Army, and its first Sirdar, and in dealing with his arduous life in Egypt he sandwiches in two ancedotes that cannot be omitted. The first is an illustration of the militant spirit then prevalent.

When the square at Abu Klea was penetrated by the Dervishes, one of them attempted to spear a gunner who was in the act of ramming home a charge. The Briton brained the Sudanese, but the rammer head split on the man's hard skull. Next day the gunner was sent for; mistaking the reason, and knowing from experience soldiers are charged for Government property they break, he led off: "Please, sir, I'm very sorry I broke the rammer, but I never thought the nigger's head could be so hard. I'll pay for the rammer so as to hear no more of the case."
The other of these stories has to do with the famous Army chaplain, Father Brindle:

Preaching one day in the desert during Lent, be said: "Now, my men. I cannot ask you here on Service to abstain, but you might do something which would be pleasing to the Almighty and will gratify me abstain fro the use of bad language." Looking into the upturned faces, he thought from their sympathetic expression he had effected some good. When the parade was dismissed he stood for a few mintues speaking to some officers, and ten mintues later, walking behind two of his recent congregation, who, talking egaerly did not notice his footage on the soft and he overheard one say, "Bill, that was a bloody fine sermon the father gave us."

div.head: THE LATE MAJOR JOHNSTONE.
div.p: From the latest advice received from London we learn that the death of the late General Manager of the Egyptian State Railways, Major L'Estrange Johnstone was due to an internal tumour. An operation was decided upon by Sir Thomas Lander Brutnon, but this afforded no relief, and the Major gradually sank.

div.head: A PLAGUE PREVENTIVE.
div.p: A pamphlet has been issued by the Asiatic Petroleum Co., Ltd., London, of which Messrs. Worms and Co. are the agents in Egypt, showing the efficacy of liquid fuel as a plague preventive. In his introductory remarks to the reports of which the pamplet consists the publisher writes:-

So long ago as 1797 it was observed by Mr. Baldwin, the British Consul in Egypt, that, among the millions of inhabitants who died of plague in that country in the space of four years, not a single oilman had suffered; and Sir J. McGregor records that all men who were employed in applying oil to the camels' feet during the Egyptian campaign escaped the plague. Mr. Jackson states that the coolies employed in the oil stores of Tunis smeared themselves with oil, and were rarely affected with plague when it raged with the city. It is not perphaps remarkable, therefore, that among the many experiments that have been made with various disinfectants, ptroleum, and finally liquid fuel, should have been tried.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: The Department of Public Health Ministry of the Interior, has applied for a futher credit of L.E 10,000 for fighting the plague, and this will be approved by the Council of Ministers at tomorrow's meeting. Today's bulletin reports the admission to hospital at Alexandria of a Greek from the Minet-el-Bassel quarter.

div.head: SUEZ BAY NAVIGATION.
div.p: Dreging operations about to be undertaken at Suez, for the purpose of cutting deep water channels, one opposite New port rock, and the other through the four-fathom bat which lies between the Spitbuoy and the Kalsa-Kebira shoals.

The dredgers will be kept working either by day or night accordidng to weather and circumstances, and will display the following signals from a crossyard on the mast: By day (between sunrise and sunset) three black ball, two placed horizontally at one end of the yard and one at the other, the two balls indicating the side on which vessels must pass. By night (between sunset and sunrise) three white fixed lights similairly arranged. The ordinary riding light will not be carried.

Mariners should make as much use as possible of the passage to the westward of the Kalsa-Kebri shoal, more especially when in deep draught vessels, in order to avoid interfering with the dreding work on the fourfathom bar. Leading marks will be placed in the vicinity of the old beacon at the head of the bay as a guide to the dredgeres, and if necessary will have lights placed on them by night.
Instrument Concerts
Every Night
On the Verandah of the
WINDSOR, HOTEL
Alexandria
From 6 to 12 p.m.
5 O'clock Tea Served on Verandah.

div.head:
THE IRRIGATION SERVICE.
BRIBERY AND CORRUPTION.
div.p: We regret that our contemporary "Le Progres" should have adopted an attitude of such optimisistc scorn towards the protests of the "Minbar" against the corruption prevalent among a certain number of the employee of the Irrigation Department. We do not see eye to eye with our Natinoalist contemporary in many matters, but sound criticism that has no political bearing deserves attention whatever its service, and there is no object to be gained by closing our eyes to certain supplesant facts. "Al Minbar" states that several of the native engineers employed by the Irrigation Department take bribes - to put matters with unpleaseant abruptness. It does not mention names owing to the absence of documentary evidence of the charge and is in our opinion unjustly blamed of its omission.

The receipients of backsheesh do not usually give receipts, nor do they proclaim the total of their gain to the world. But when an employe in receipt of from L.E 15 or less to L.E 20 per mensem, becomes in a brief space of time the owner of a couple of hundred feddans of good land, keeps a large establishment, and without heritage or windfall, happy investment or overt robbery beceomes a comparatively sudden affluence deman investigation.

We grant that it is easy to suspect corruption difficulty to prove it, and that the task of the Irrigation Department, never easy, is rendered peculiarly difficult by the secrecy of such transactions as those at which we have hinted. But the evil exists, of that we are convinced, and that the administration can only win credit by redoubling its efforts to eradicate it.

div.head: SUDAN IRRIGATION SERVICE.
div.p: The Sudan Government has decided to create three new teftish in connection with the Sudan Irrigation Service in the provinces of Kassals, Upper Nile, and Gajireh.

The chief inspector of the Sultan Irrigations is expected to arrive here next week and is accompanied by several British engineers, one of whom will be appointed to the Khartoum service at a salary of L.E. 1,000 while the others will be appointed to the provinces at salaries ranging from L.E. 360 to L.E. 480.

div.head: THE DATTARI COLLECTION AT CAIRO.
div.p: The July August number of the "Revue Archeologique" give the place of hoour to an article by M. Salomon Reiush describing, with the aid of several pictures and the three photo graveures, two of the most valuable antiquities in the collection of Dattari of Cairo. These are a bronze statuette and a marble head, both assigned to Alexander the Great. The statuette shows the macedonian as a youth, ridiing a cheveal, but the horse is unfrotunately missing. The hero is nude except for a head fress descending over the left shoulder, made up of the scalp with trunk, and part of the skin covering the neck of a young elephant, and article of apparel familiar in statues of Alexander and also in some representing the city of Alexandria. The figure will be famous for the perfection of the anatomical rendering of the body. The elephant skin served as a shield to the left arm, whilst the right evidently held a javelin, or spear. The head represetns Alexander at a mature age, and is particularly similar to another head of him which is now known only by a drawing. It is to be hoped that these two valuable relices will always remain in Egypt, which will then possess two of the most important representaions of Alexander, who by the creation of the great city named after him deserved so wll of the country.

div.head: A PAPYRUS FIND.
div.p: Among a number of Egyptian papri purchased for the Museum at Wuzbrug, Dr. Wilcken has detected that a quantity of fragments were occupoed with some important historical work. With great care the pieces were assorted as as to produce a legible text with the result that we have resotred to us what is believed to be a portion of the lost biography entitled the "Deeds of Hannibal" whose author was Sosylas, a companion and sort of mentor to the great warrior. The editio principes of the fragment may be found in the German philiogical journal "Hermes" for last January. Perhaphs now that the stype of writing is known futher portions of the manuscript may be found in collections of papyri in other museums.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Sirdar intens to make a three weeks' stay in Cairo and will then proceed to Kordofan on a tour of inspection.
Sir William Garstin leaves Europe today of Egypt.

Mr. Perceival W. Chataway, President of the Alexandria Municipality, resumed his functions yesterday immendiately on his arrival. We are glad to learn that Mr. Chataway his entriely recovered from his recent long and serious illness.
The Khedive has conferred the rank of Sanieh on Mustapha Bey Neguih, son of Ibrahim Pasha Neguib, Under-Secretary of State to the Ministry of the Interior.
Lady Anne Blunt will arrive in Egypt early in November.
Sir Horace Pinching is expected to return on the 17th inst.
Mr. Joseph Khalil has been promoted to the office of boos-chief de bureau at the Ministry of Finance.

Among the latest arrivals at the Savoy Hote, Port Said, have been Major Stack, Capt. Vanugban, Colonel Campbell, Miss Graham, Mr. P. Wiehr, Mr. R. Murray, Mr. and Mrs. Danchell, Mr. I. Kramer, Mr. Hutchinson, Mr. David F. Williams, Dr. Andreiades, Mr. Bard, Mr. Kemel, Mr. S.S. Bagge, Mr. G.D. Collins, Mr. Maksud, Mme Hodeir, Mr. Ferrari, Mr. C.E.C Peach, Mr. H Beltram.

div.head: THE PHARAOHS AND SINAI.
div.p: A French historical student writing in the "Revue des Idees." throws an interesting light upon Egypt's efforts for the possession of the Sinani Peninsula which go back far beyond the Christian era. Indeed, the struggle appearst o be as old as Egypt itself. There is history to bear ipon it. So long as 4,700 year ago, the Pharaoh Mersekhs, of the Thi ite dynasty, asserted sovereignty, as is proved by stales of his reign that have been found on the peninsula. Later the struggle was carried by the Pharaohs of the twelfth dynasty, and was maintained with still greater vigour, when Syria and the caravan routes passed under the dominion of the Asyrians. The reason for Egypt's pertinancity is simplicity itself. The peninsula was to ancient Egypt what the Danute was to medieval Europe - the avenue by which all the wines, silks, perfumes, and rich commerce of Asia found their way into the country. And Egypt could not tolerate that the narrow connecting link between her and this avenue should be in possibly hostile hands. And after nearly 5,000 years the might of modern England is used to preserve the sentiment of a tradition that has for age lost all real practical importance.

div.head: AMERICAN TRADE IN EGYPT.
div.p: The United States agent at Alexnadria, Mr. Charles M. Pepper, in his reort to Washington, says that Egypt, in the commerical sense, is the most promising terriotry bordering the Mediterranean anywhere from the Straits of Gibraltar ot the Red Sea.

For the principal articles of import the markets are substantially as acessible to the United States as to Great Britain, which has the largest share of the commerce, the differences in distance not being so important when ocean freights are considred as when the traffice is dependent on railway transportation.

Great Britain's lead is undisputed, especially in textiles, and she is also well in advance in iron and steel productions. The Egyptian demand for motor cars, motor cycles, and even bicyles is an increasing one, and this applies not only to Cairo and Alexandria, wehre the most epxensive machines are in favour, and where motor buses and traction cars are in use, but also to the interior.
Mr. Peper suggests a parmenet American exposition in Egypt for the purpose of making Americam goods known. Machienry, and particularly agricultural machinery, should be the principal feature.

div.head: UM RUS OPERATIONS.
div.p: The Progress report for the half month ending September 17, states "Main shaft section - 650 ft. level crosout extended 33 ft. total 118 ft., at which point the vein was cut; quartz 6 inwide, shows no trace of glod in the pan." Reference to our plan of last Saturday will show that we have been correct in our assumption as to the position of the lords, which , as per above cable, has now been out So far there are no traces of gold, but there is still a possibliity of values being encountered on driving further into the lode.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd hiu a midi et demie.)

La hausee enorms du taux d'ecompte de 4 a 5% a la Banque d'Augleterre et de 4 3/8 a 4 ¾ dans le reste du pays a produit un cretain malaise aur notre place. Aussi aton onvert ce matin en raction sensible mais dans la suite de la séance il y a eu repirse et la cloture s'affectue en hausse partielle; un certain nombre de titres restent cependant au-dessous des cours precedents. Quant aux affaires, outre qu'elles se sont limitees comme precedemment a une certaine catageorie de valeurs et qu'elles ont ete presque toutes pour fin, elles ont ete peu nombreuses.
L'Agricole est un pen plus ferme a 9 11/16, tandis que la National Bank est offerte a 2 ¾ avec affaires.
De 7 3/16 la Ramleh Railway flechit d'un coup a 7 7 1/6 a cause de quelques offeces de ventes.
Plus faibles aussi les privlegiees Tramways d'Alexandrie flechissent de 189 a 188 ½, l' Alexandria Water de 13 ¾ a 13 5/8 et les actions Eauz du Caire de 124 a 123.
Les Egyptian Markets restent demandes, ce qui fait monter le prix de 27/3 a 27/6 scheteurs.
On offre, par contre, la Salt and Soda a 22 shellings.
L'Obligation Credit Foncier Egyptian perd un tranc a 337.
Que' ques transactions ont en lieu en Cassa di Sconto qui se maintient au meme cours, du moins la nouvelle emission, car l'ancienne perd 50 centimes a 299.
L'Anglo-American Niles est tant soit oue plus soutenne a 5 13/32.
De 144 la Banque d'Athenes s'avance a 141 ½ acheteurs.
Les Nungovich Hotels, sur quelques relisations, flechissent de 17 15/16 a 17 ¾.
Par Contre, les Delta Land Sont l'object d'une demande sulvie quie pouse le prix 3 19/2 a 3 21/32.
En hausse marquee la Nile Land s'avance de 15 15/16 a 16 ¼.
Les Sucreries et Raffinerie d'Egypte reactionent encore d'une franc a 24.
Depuis quelque temps l'Investment baissait gradullement et de facon continue. Il vient de se relever brusquement 1 3/16 a 1 1/17 achetrus.
Ls. Land Bank recule de 1/16 a 8 15/16 sans donte an sympathic avec la bourse de Paris.
Une antre valeur qui fait preuve de bonno tendance, c'est l'Ubraine, dont le prix remonte de 6 ¼ a 6 5/16 acheterurs.
La Comptoir fait preuve de soutien, excepte l'ancienne emission preuve de soutien, excepte l'ancienne emission qui perd 1/32 a 7 livres acheturs, ainisi que le Credit Franco-Egyptien a 5 5/16.
Quant a la Banque d'Orient, elle perd 25 centimes a 131 ½.
Le reste du marche demure sanc changement.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES

Le taux de l'escompte libre a Londres a hausse 1/8 a 4 ½ pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolide anglaise a encour gane hier `/8 a 86 ½. L'Unifiee est restee invaries a 104 1.4 de meme que la National Bank a 26 7/8 l'Agricole a 9 ¾, la Daira a 16 7/8 et la Delta Light a 11 5/8.
A Paris, l'action Credit Froncier Egyptian a retrograde de 1 franc a 774. La Banque d'Athenes est demeuree inchanges a 144. L'emprunt russe 1906 a reactionne de 83.20 a 83.10.

Ici, la tendance genearle se maintient ferme. Le compartiment des tires dirigeants a ete, il est vrasi, calme, aveo des transcations tres clairsemees; mais, en revanche, les affaires praquess ont ete nombreuses dans les autres groupes, notamment dans celui des petites valeurs.
Dans l'ensemble , l'orientation semble etre toujours a la hausse, retenue en grande partis par la penurie d'or dont la fin ne saurait se produire avant les premirs jours la semaine prochaine.

La National Bank a ete traitee a 26 ¾-13/6. L'Agricole est restee a 9 11/16. La Cassa di Sconto a molli a 227-228. La Bauque d'Orient a progresse a 132 et le Comptoir Fnancier a a debute a 7 pour atteindre 7 1/6 et revenir en clouture 6 15/16 7. La Banque' Abyssainie est remontee a 5 9/16.

Le Credit Foncier a ete bien tenn a 777. La Diara a progresse a 16 7/8. La part de founteur Immobriliere a passe de 735 a 740. L'action Entreprise and Development a ete remenee a 12 13.16 et le part de fondatuer a 22. Les Improvements ont fait 5 11/16 ¾.

Tres mouvementee, l'action Entreprises Immobilierres et Travaux a tteint 4 ½, ache teurs, our fiuri a 4 7/16 ½; la part de foundateur, tres recherchee, a hausee a 93 pour clouturer a 91. L'action Allotment s'est consolidee a 3 3/8 et la foundateur a 127.
Les Automoblies out eu en beau depart a 6 13/16 pour reactionner a 6 ½; 'a part de foundateur a avance a 12 pour fioir a 11 ¾. Les Jouissances Eaux de Caire se sont alourdies a 262.

Dans le groupe des valeurs hotelieres, le Nungovich ont ete pousses a 18 pour finir a 17 15/16-18. Les Egyptian ont avance a 1/4 de livre a 6 11/16-3/4. Les Upper Egypt ont ete re cherche a 5 1/8. La part a de fondateur National Hotel a progresse a 62.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont gagne tenue, ont atteint les abords de 3 ¾ por revenir, sur des realisation, a 5/8. Un mouvement sigficatif de hausse s'est egalement dessine sur les New Egyptian, qui ont passe de 29 a 31 h., acheteurs. Les Markets ont avance a 27 sh. 3 et les Salt and Soda a 22 sh. Les Estates sont restes a 1 15/16; leur part de fondatuer a progresse a 12 13/16-7/8.
Nous detachons d'une lettre de Paris, en date du 3 Octobre, le passage suivant:

Les retraits d;or de la Bauque d'Augleterre ont recommence a reprendre a de grandes proportions. Depuis le dernier bilan (26 Septembre) les sorties ont atteint £10,000 pour l'Egypte et le reste pour l;Amerique et diverses autres destinations. Les besoius des Etate-Unis sont, parait-il, loin d'etre satisfaits. La position des Bauques associees de New York s'est toutefois quelque peu ameliorea. Yourjours est-il que le marche de Londres ne se coit pas encore a l'abri de nouvelles saignees de la part de'Amerique et on criot que la Banque d'Angleterre pourrait bien se voir obligee d'elever le taux officiel de l'escompte a 4 ½ pour cent.
L'assemblee generale ordinarie des actionaires de la Societe des Tramways Electriques du Caire aura lieu au siege social a Bruxrllrd le 17 Octobre courant.
Carnet de l'actionaire

Les actionuaires de l'Egyptian Turst and Investment Ltd. (Glymenopoulo) en liquidation, sont prevenus que les versements des deme et Seme appels de 5 sh. devront etre effectues a l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank avant le 30 Octobre courant; faute de quoi ils ne pnrront plus echanger leurs titres contre des actions Building Lands. Depuis hier, les retardataires sont passibles d'un interet de 20% l'an.
Les recettes des Tramways d'Alexandrie pour la semaine au 6 Octovre courant se sont elevees a L.E. 1,786 contre 1,553 et 1905, soit en augmentation de L.E 233.
Les recettes totales depuis le 1er Janvier 1906 ont atteint L.E. 63,095 contre 53.454 en 1905, soit on plus value de L.E. 9,642 pour l'exercise courant.
Le recettes des Egyptian Markets pour la semaine au 4 Octobre se sont chifrees par L.E. 483 contre 400 en 1905, soit en augmentation de L.E. 83.
Les recettes totales de l'exercise en cours ont atteint L.E. 25,815 contre 19,266 en 1905, soit en plus value de L.E. 6,549.

div.head:
IRISH AGARIAN OUTRAGE.
NATIONAL LEADERS RESPONSABLE.

div.p: A long standing land dispute near Athenry (Galway) culminated yesterday in an agrarian outrage. 16 men attacked and moratlly wounded a constable who was protecting the legal receiver.
The "Times" attributes the outrage to the recent inflammatory cratory of the Nationalist leaders and emphasizes the danger of granting the demands of the Irish extremists. (Reuter)

div.head:
ITALY'S NEW ARMAMENTS.
GENERAL'S SENSATIONAL SPEECH.

div.p: General E. Pedotti, formerly the Minister of War and now the commander of the IVth Army Corps, speaking at Turin, said that Italy's new armaments were the best gurantee that her integrity would be maintained from the Alps to Auarnero. The speech has caused a sensation as the Quareno is Austrian, and in view of the strained relations at present existing between Italy and Austria. (Reuter)

The "Daily Telegraph" learns that three warships, offically styled cruisers, which are being built on the Clyde and at Elswick, are really battleships, less armoured byt faster than the Freadnough. Each vessel will carry eight 12 inch guns and the speed will be 25 knots an hour. (Reuter)
The Congress of Constitutional Democrats has adopted a resoltion declaring that passive resistance is impossible. (Reuter)
Eighty four battalions occupying different districts in Macedonia have been withdrawn. (Havas)

div.head:
WIRELESS TELEGRAPHY CONFERENCE.
NO DIVERGENCY OF VIEWS.

div.p: The "Daily Mail's" report regarding the isolation of Great Britain and the divergency of views at the Wireless Telegraphy conference has been offically denied. (Reuter)

div.head:
SWANSEA COLLIERY ESTATES.
SALE TO FRENCH SYNDICATE.

div.p: Negotiations with regard to the sale to a French syndicate of five colliery estates in the Swanea Vally are proceeding. (Reuter)
The "Daily Telegraph" learns from Tokio that Japan is negotiating with Russia for the establishment of an overland service of mails which will take seventeen days to reach Tokio from London. (Reuter)
The publication of the memoirs of Prince Hohenlohe, relating to persons still living is still the subject of much dicussion. (Havas)
The National Assembly began its sittings on the 7th inst. and elected as president the ex-Minister Sameleed Aouled Khan. (Reuter)
The railway from Luderitz Bay to Kubub (Damaraland) has been opened for traffic. (Reuter)

div.head:
LORD ELGIN'S DESPATCH.
AGITATION IN MALTA.

div.p: The agitation against Lord Elgin's despatch proclaiming religious equality is growing. A monster meeting has been convened for Sunday "to denounce the cowardly depostism of the British Government." (Reuter)

Lord Elgin's despatch beaing upon the liberty of worship in Malta is arousing a spririt of bitter hostility. The leading Italian paper, whilst declaring that it awaits the eccelesiastical action of the Archbiship of the islands, says, with regard to the potlical situation created by the Colonial Minister's instructions, that the conditions under which Malata was give by its inhabitants as a mere protectorate to England have illgeally violated,that the Maltese are being assassinated in the religious sesne by the protecting Power, that the Church equality imposed constitues an enormity which might be expected from Turkey or Russia, and that nevertheless a refusal to tolerate will call into action English guns and bayonets.

div.head:
THE VIBORG MANIFESTO.
EXTREME POLICY ABANDONED.

div.p: The decision of the Consittutional Democrats denotes the abandoment of the extreme policy of the Viborg manifesto and the reversion to more mdoerate counsels. (Reuter)

At a meeting of the committee of the deputation to Russia, yesterday evening, it was decided to await futher advice form the Anglo Russian frienship committee at St.Petersburg before completing the arrangements for the journey. The visit to Moscow has been abandoned. (Reuter)
The English deputation will deliver its address to the president of the Duma in privates audience. (Havas)

div.head:
BODIES EXHUMED AT LODZ.
COSSACKS DIPERSE THE CROWD.

div.p: A crowd yesterday marched to the executiion square and exhumed the bodies of five terrorits who had been tried by drum head court matiral and shot in the morning. They were beginning to collect money to purchase coffins when the Cossacks arrived and dispersed the crowed with swords and whips. Many were injured in the scuffle which ensued.

div.head: THE STRENUOUS LIFE.
div.p: A warning is uttered by the "Practitioner" against the dangers of the strenuous life. It is good to be strennous, says our contemporary, but it is also good, as the poet tell us, to play the fool, or, at any rate, to be idle at the right time and in the right way. This is just what the strenuous man forgets, and the consequences is too often premature breakdown - a common event in the storm and stress of modern life. The strenuous life is helping to overcrowd our asylums. We need to learn to incalculable value of rest. This consits, not in a change of excitement or in hard work, disguished as a game, but in genuine repose. A man who knows how to rest from labour will live longer and accomplished more than one who allows the fever of strenuous living to fret his mind and body to premature decay.

div.head: MALTA OVER POPULATED.
div.p: The courts of justice and the schools of Malta were reopened yesterday week the latter by the Deputy Governor, Major General Barron, who in his speech laid stress on the fact that in all ages Malta was held by world ruling Powers, that its history is an epitome of the history of the world. He added, however, that the Maltese are grown over numerous for the size of their island, and must now establish themselves in the broader world, with which their race was ever in contact.

div.head: THE HUSBAND OF THE FUTURE.
div.p: Writing on "the Husband of the Future" in "Madame," Mrs. Leonard Marashall says:-

"Imagine the comfort of having one's husaband to cook one's dinner, of finding one's slipers on a winter's eving, toasting by a bright, clean harth after a weary day in the black City. Think of that beautiful but perhaps impossible Ideal, the husband who never grumbles, never talks of expense, never fumes when the boys want new school books, or makes a scene when his wife refuses to go out because 'she has nothing to wear.' The Ideal would never by any chance abuse his wifr's blood relations, spend his evenings at the club and his Saturdays cycling with his men friends who have pretty sistesr, cousins, and aunts. A man, in short, who never did any of the thousands and one objectionable things the common or garden husband wont to do. Would not any women gladly descent into the area and fight her way to the front, just to keep such a domestic pet."

div.head: KAMEL PASHA INTERVIEWED.
div.p: "MISERABLE TYPES" OF SYRIANS.

Mustapha Pasha Kamel has been intereviewed by the Paris correspondent of the "Pall Mall Gazette." It will be observed that he appears to detest the Syrians as much as his brother, Aly Bey Fehmy, whose recent outburst of spleen against them ended by his paying a visit to the Syrian Editors at Cairo to aplogise. "Miserable types" is the Pasha's apellation, and he evidently intends to make short work of them as soon as he has got rid of the English. Another inetresting point is the Pasha;s symbolism as exemplified in his contemptuously kicking at a chair, part of the furniture of the Hotel des Illes Britanniques, when spearking about Lord Cromer: -

Mustapha Kamel Pasha was sitting in the Hotel des Iles Britanniques. A red fez was on his head; in his hand a pen. He was corresponding for dear life. An intelligent face features lighted by brown eyes and set off by an elegant moustache; a nervous, agile figure. Abigger contrast with the type of conquering Briton could hardly be supposed.

Kamel Pasha rose on my entrace and showed an instatn readiness to talk. I explained my business. the agitation in Egypt, the despatch of troops, men in arms kept in reserve in Cairo. The Egyptian laughed a quick laugh. He speaks voluble French and he replied in that language, "Yes; we know the story of the agitation. Pan Islamism serves the purposes of our rulers, but it is not true. There is no agitation, there is no conspiracy. Our movement is an orderly and peaceful manifestation of the national spirit. We have no hatred on the English, as it supposed. We simply say that Lord Cromer, by his treatment of us, is the wrost friend Great Britain could have. He had an admirable opportunity of winning our love, but he has acted as oppressor, as tryant.

"What makes his tyranny the harder to bear is that it is always wrapped up in legal forms. Take the case of Denishwai. 'These men have been convicted by the highest tribunal' says Lord Cromer. But what a tribunal. The native judge is a emre functionary; he has no independence; he can be removed at the will of those who palced him there.

"The detestable fact in the governance of Egypt is the hypocriny which is over everything. As autocrat or tyrant, recognised as such, simpy imposes his will. Lor Crommer omposes his will just as surely, but through the forms of law. He is an autocrat as great as Adul Hamid, the Tzar, or the Kaiser.

"We claim to be treated as human beings, not as slaves, as pieces of furniture" - and the sneaker contemptuously kicked at a chair. "We are constantly being made to feel that we are inferior race. In what way are we inferior . I am sure the fllaheen are as intelligent as the lwoer classes in England and as capabel of self-goverment. We ask for a Constituion for an Egyptian Parliament, such as was promised to us when the regime of the Khedive Twefik was suppressed. For twenty-four years we have waited for that Parliament.
The Tutelage of Germany.

"Our enemies declare that we are anxious to come under the Ottoman rule, to become, in fact as well as in name, the subjects of the Turk. This is absolutely false. Do you imagine we should wish to palce ourselves under such a Governemnt. Very far from that, I assure you. In the same way, we have no wish to come under the tutelage of Germany. No, no. We wish to remain Egyptians, and not to become Turks, or English or Germans or French, or any other nationality. Our character is the Treaty of London, 1840, establishing our neutraily under the guarantee of Europe. That is the states we wish to have restored to us.

"Our position has become ten fold wore since the Anglo-French treaty confirming the BRitish in the occupation of our country. Hre was opportunity to show the Egyptians that the English were determined to carry out their mission with due regard to national sentiment; but, instead of that, they have proved more arrogant than ever. The English never associate with us; they keep always to themselves, and konw nothing of local sentiment.

"To show you what the present temper of our rulers is, let me give you an instance. After the Denishwai affair, in which the death penalty was carried out, although medical evidence showed that Captain Bull did not die of his injuries, but of heart-failure through exhaustion, some Greeks set upon two English officers in the streets of Cairo and beat them. They also, beat the police officers charged with inquiring into the affair. For this offence they were sent to their Consulate and sentenced simply to twenty days imprisonment. Observe the difference of treatment in the two cases. It shows that England is checked by the smallest foreign nation covered by the Capitulations, and is only tyrannical towards us, the Egyptians.
"It si not singular that Lord Cromer should now be calling loudly for troops when, at the farewell banquet to Mr. Eldon Gorst, he said, "Opposition is broken!"
A Centre of Un-British Propaganda.

Whilst the conversation continied other Egyptians entered the room. It was evident that this little hotel in the Rne de la Paix named, as if by irony. "Les Illes Britanniques," had become a centre of un British propanganda. Each took his share in the general accusation.

Said one, an ex-professor: "This question of education is a burning one Under the Khedivial dynasty we had schools which were free to the poor; to day the fellah cannot send his child to school, the fees are too high"

Kamel Pasha again took up the threads of conversation. "We make no charge against the personnel character of Lord Cromer. On the contrary, and I have always said it, his private life is irresporachable and his absolute honesty above suspicion. But he has no sympathy with national aspiration. The policy in Egypt is much less liberal than it is in India. One fo the greates faults of Lord Cromer is that he gathers about him unworthy instruments in the csomopolitan populations of Cairo. Some of the Syrians are miserable types and do not represent the Egyptian nation.

"Yet though we have many grievances, principally of th emoral order, we are not prejudiced against the English," he protested. "Do I not teach English in my native school at Cairo!" And thus quiantly the conversation ended.

div.head: THE SULTAN'S PROJECTS.
div.p: Without being solicited, the Sultan has granted concession to the Minister of Justice for the much desired electric tramway between Soutari and Kedikeni, important surburbs on the Asiatic coast of the Bosphorus, and to the son of the Sheik ul Islam for a railway from Aleepo to the coast. Another concession has been gratned to Zekki Pasha, Grand Master of the Artillery, for the electric lighting go Constantinople. The sudden granting of these much sought after concession to people who did not ask for them gives rise to much commment. It can only be interpreted as showing the Sultan's desire to conciliate these personages, especially when it is remebered that the Minister of Justice represents the Old Turkey Party, and in the Council of Minsiters invariably shows great opposition to all projects for loans, conversion, etc. The Sheik ul Islam is naturally the leader of the religious party, and Zekki Pasha is the representative of the military party. It is generally supposed that this is the first step towards winning over the above to assits the Sultan's scheme for altering the order of the sucession in favour of his son, Burhan eddin.

div.head: MOTHER-MARTYRS.
div.p: "I could not bear the children to be near me, for the constant struggle to bear such agony as I endured quite qore out my nerves," said Mrs. Jenkins, of 46. Ann-street, Cilfynydd, near Pontypridd. Yet after two years of intense suffering, this lady has foundin Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People not only relief from pain, but a complete restoration of health.

"After the birth of one of my children," said Mrs. Jenkins, "I was laid up with rhenmatic fever and became reduced to a terribly weak state. I never exptected to get about again. My legs swelled, and pains shot through my body so acute that I could have screamed out. No medical skill seemed able to help me; for in spite of medicine I grew weaker and weaker. My appetiate left me, I was a white as a sheet, and suffered tortures of indigestion after taking food. For two years I was a complete invalid - helpless, and a burden to everybody. Day after day, I was pillowed up in the same room, incapable of moving. My heart was weak, and I had fainting fits if a knock came at the door.
I got into such a low state at last that no one was allowed to visits me. I did not seem to live at all.
"Finally a friend told my husband to give me Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People, and he thoughfully bought a box for me.

"I took them, merly hoping that they might cease my suffering a little, but I was surpised at the good they did me. The pains were relived and I was encouraged by a feeling of brightness and improved appetite to continue taking them. Gradually I felt more strenght coming, and found myself eating really solid meals, and enjoying food. I had no trace of indigestion, and all pains had long since ceased. Soon I was able to get ourdoor and my former strength came back completely. My recovery after two years of such illness amazed everybody who know me. I am now a strong and active woman again, with no trouble, and able to do my day's work with ease, thanks to Dr. Williams' Pink Pills.
"My husband a little time ago had an attack of great weakness, but after taking Dr. Williams' Pink Pills he was soon more robust than ever."

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsbiel for the opinions expressed by our coresspondents in a spirit of fair play to all to permit - within certain necessary limits free discussion.

div.head: THE NATIONALIST PRESS.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir. - With great interst I read your leading article in your yesterday's issue under the heading "El Minbar." Every one expected from the proprietors of "El Minbar" a better policy the present situation, owing to their long experience in the journal world. Mr. Hafez Awad cannot blame the Sudan Government for refusing his paper from entering the Sudan, a country which is still in a savage state and under reform. Of course the reforemrs of such a country require a help and not a hindrance to their worthy and hard task. I should like to understand why Mr. Hafez Award does not blame the Turkish Government for refusing nearly al the National Moselm journals of Egypt to enter the Ottoman Empire, and if I am not mistaken the "El Minbar" and "El Lewa" are included. Why do not they ask Mustapha Kamel to show his eloquence in Turkey, or at least to make his way by Stambol on his return to Egypt and then to say what he saw, what he heard, and how he was treated in the Capital and submit it to the general ipinon to compre and judge.
With thanks, I remain, Sir, Yours faithfully,

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.

div.head: FRESKEL.
div.p: WHAT IT IS
FRESKEL is a dry powdered preparation for Wall and Ceiling Decoration, made ready for use with the addition of water.
It is easily prepared and applied.
WHAT IT DOES
FRESKEL, covers well, and works easy Does not crack, peel, or show brush marks. Does not rub off.
ECONOMICAL - EFFECTIVE.

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig. 21416 31-12.905
